title: How to Make Candied Lemons

steps.headline: Wash and slice the lemons.
steps.description: Wash 4 lemons and use a sharp knife to slice them into very thin slices. You should get about 6 slices from each lemon. Discard any seeds and set the lemon slices aside. Try to use organic lemons since these haven't been sprayed with pesticides and you'll be eating the peels.

steps.headline: Prepare an ice bath.
steps.description: Since you'll be blanching the lemon slices, you'll need to quickly cool them down after you've boiled them. Get out a medium-sized bowl and fill it about 3/4 full of ice. Pour water over the ice so it comes a few inches from the top of the bowl.

steps.headline: Boil the lemon slices for 1 minute.
steps.description: Fill a large pot of water and put it on the stove. Turn the heat to high so the water begins to boil. Add all of the lemon slices and let them boil for 1 minute. Turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Transfer the lemon slices to the ice bath.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to carefully scoop the lemon slices out of the hot water and immediately put them into the ice water. Leave the lemon slices in the ice water until they're cold. This should take a few minutes. Blanching the lemon slices will soften them, but stop them from cooking so they keep their bright yellow color.

steps.headline: Make a sugar syrup.
steps.description: Place a large skillet on the stove and combine 2 cups (400 g) of granulated sugar and 2 cups (480 ml) of water in it. Turn the heat to medium and stir the mixture occasionally. Cook it for several minutes so the sugar dissolves and turns into a syrup.

steps.headline: Add the lemon slices and simmer them for 1 hour.
steps.description: Use the slotted spoon to remove the lemon slices from the ice bath and place them in the skillet. The lemon slices should be in a single layer so they cook evenly. The syrup should be bubbling gently. Simmer the slices for 1 hour so the rinds become clear and the lemons are soft. You can stir the lemons occasionally to help them cook evenly, but ensure that they stay in a single layer.

steps.headline: Cool the lemon slices on a wire rack.
steps.description: Place a wire rack next to the skillet. Use a slotted spoon to carefully lift the lemon slices out of the syrup and place them on the wire rack. Let them sit out until they're completely cool. You may want to lay a sheet of waxed paper underneath the rack to catch any syrup that drips.

steps.headline: Use and store the candied lemon slices.
steps.description: Once the slices are cool to the touch, you can use them as a garnish for fancy desserts or baked goods. For example, place lemon slices on cupcakes, cakes, or in cocktails. If you have leftover lemon slices, place them in an airtight container and refrigerate them. You can store the candied lemon slices for up to 1 month.

steps.headline: Wash and cut the lemons.
steps.description: Wash 4 large lemons and use a sharp knife to carefully cut each lemon into 4 big wedges. Slice away the peel and white part from the fruit. Try to keep the peel in big pieces and then slice each piece into long, thin strips. Use organic lemons if you can. Since you'll be eating the peel, you don't want them to be sprayed with pesticides.

steps.headline: Cook the strips of lemon peel for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Put all of the lemon peel strips into a saucepan and pour in enough water to cover them. Put the pan on the stove and turn the heat to high. Bring the water to a boil and then turn the heat down so the water bubbles gently. Simmer the lemon peels for 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Cook the strips of lemon peel in fresh water for 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Place a colander in the sink and carefully drain the water from the lemon peels. Put the lemon peels back in the saucepan and add fresh, cold water to cover the peels. Turn the heat back to high so the water begins to boil. Turn the heat down so the water simmers and cook the lemon peel for 5 more minutes. Drain the lemon peel into the colander. Simmering the lemon peel in a new batch of water will soften the peel and get rid of the bitterness in the lemons' peel.

steps.headline: Make a sugar syrup.
steps.description: Put a large skillet on the stove and combine 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar and 3/4 cup (180 ml) of water in it. Turn the heat to medium and stir the mixture occasionally so the sugar dissolves. Cook it for several minutes so it turns into a syrup.

steps.headline: Add the lemon peel and simmer them for 50 to 60 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer the lemon peel from the colander to the syrup in the pan. Turn the heat to medium-low so the syrup bubbles gently. Simmer the lemon peel for 50 to 60 minutes. The peel should become shiny and almost clear. You don't need to stir while the lemon peel simmers because the lemon peels may break. Just ensure that they're covered with the syrup.

steps.headline: Bake the lemon peels for 1 hour.
steps.description: Preheat an oven to 150 degrees F (65 degrees C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Carefully scoop the lemon peels out of the syrup and put them on the baking sheet. Bake the peels for 1 hour. They should be completely dry.

steps.headline: Use and store the lemon peels.
steps.description: You can garnish your favorite desserts with the candied lemon peel or dip them in melted chocolate. Let the chocolate harden and serve the chocolate dipped lemon peels with other candied fruits. Store any leftover candied lemon peel in an airtight container in the refrigerator. You can store the lemon peel for 6 to 8 weeks.
